rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 (electronic music)}
{\rtf1 So in this lab, we're now\par dealing with certificates,}
{\rtf1 not encrypted traffic, we're\par not looking at it at all.}
{\rtf1 We're just looking at the\par certificate that was passed}
{\rtf1 so that the two could\par communicate and negotiate keys.}
{\rtf1 So we're basically, before\par encrypted data's going in}
{\rtf1 and being secure communication,\par a certificate was passed}
{\rtf1 from either the server or client,}
{\rtf1 and it has some information\par in it we can use}
{\rtf1 to identify unauthorized, abnormal,}
{\rtf1 suspicious, and benign traffic.}
{\rtf1 So what we're doing in this lab is}
{\rtf1 we're taking a bunch of traffic}
{\rtf1 from the top one million sites}
{\rtf1 and a bunch of traffic from\par contagio pcaps, malware pcaps,}
{\rtf1 with command and control,\par encrypted botnet activity,}
{\rtf1 just all this different stuff.}
{\rtf1 And we're going to analyze\par just the certificates}
{\rtf1 and figure out what's going on.}
{\rtf1 Specifically this lab is\par showing different ways}
{\rtf1 we can analyze certificate\par information to make this work.}
{\rtf1 The data from this lab is from from Bro,}
{\rtf1 and there's technically SSL and x509 logs.}
{\rtf1 We're primarily going to\par be looking at the SSL logs.}
{\rtf1 So let's go ahead and jump in.}
{\rtf1 For this exercise we're going to\par be looking at the certificates}
{\rtf1 to see if field data's missing,}
{\rtf1 'cause that's pretty common with malware.}
{\rtf1 We're going to be looking\par at the top one million sites}
{\rtf1 versus non-top one million sites}
{\rtf1 and trying to see what that looks like,}
{\rtf1 getting a picture basically\par kind of more normal traffic}
{\rtf1 versus the unknown, and\par there's a big discrepancy.}
{\rtf1 We're also going to try to\par filter out false positives}
{\rtf1 related to the internal domain,}
{\rtf1 which for this lab is test.int.}
{\rtf1 We're also going to look\par at certificate validity.}
{\rtf1 Malware certificates often will\par have long-range expirations}
{\rtf1 like 10 years plus, because they\par want to be valid for forever.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to look for\par things like certificates}
{\rtf1 that are valid for more than 2,000 days.}
{\rtf1 Are they malicious, are\par they not--what's going on?}
{\rtf1 A lot of this lab is\par false positive reduction.}
{\rtf1 Now a lot of what we talk about\par is false positive reduction}
{\rtf1 because frankly it just matters.}
{\rtf1 You can't detect abnormal or evil}
{\rtf1 if you can't handle the\par many false positives.}
{\rtf1 So I'm giving you detection techniques}
{\rtf1 in not only how to find new things}
{\rtf1 but also how to clear out, you know,}
{\rtf1 find the needle in the haystack}
{\rtf1 by eliminating all that noise.}
{\rtf1 So a lot of that's in this lab.}
{\rtf1 Then we're going to try\par to use frequency scores.}
{\rtf1 We're going to try to use that\par natural language processing}
{\rtf1 to identify random information\par within a certificate.}
{\rtf1 Where are there false positives?}
{\rtf1 Where are there not?}
{\rtf1 What's a good threshold so we\par don't have to throw the * gap?}
{\rtf1 And we're going to go through that.}
{\rtf1 So let's go ahead and start.}
{\rtf1 First thing I'm going to do here}
{\rtf1 is we're going to preload a dashboard.}
{\rtf1 Rather than just constantly\par having you build out dashboard,}
{\rtf1 this one we're just doing analysis.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to load the\par lab 2 3 x509 dashboard.}
{\rtf1 In here you can see tons\par of information already.}
{\rtf1 We've got the frequency\par score visualizations.}
{\rtf1 We have a bar chart that\par shows whether or not}
{\rtf1 data's missing in a specific field,}
{\rtf1 which is this x509 missing\par fields visualization.}
{\rtf1 We see a metric because I\par want to see the overall count}
{\rtf1 as we apply filters to see\par how many certificate logs}
{\rtf1 match the criteria and the most\par common certificate issuers.}
{\rtf1 And we're going to browse through these}
{\rtf1 and see what we can have.}
{\rtf1 First thing I want to do is\par analyze things for missing fields.}
{\rtf1 So in here, this data if it's filled out}
{\rtf1 means it's missing that field.}
{\rtf1 So missing organization\par is the least common.}
{\rtf1 That's constantly filled out.}
{\rtf1 Now again though, we have top\par one million traffic in here}
{\rtf1 and malware traffic, so by default}
{\rtf1 all the visualizations don't mean anything}
{\rtf1 because it's too much of a\par mix of good and bad traffic.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to start\par diving through this.}
{\rtf1 Alright, first thing's first.}
{\rtf1 Let's look at the top one million sites.}
{\rtf1 These are expected to be\par more likely to be normal.}
{\rtf1 If we do that, looking\par at the missing fields,}
{\rtf1 the organization field\par is almost always there.}
{\rtf1 In fact, I'd have to hone in here}
{\rtf1 even to try to highlight this.}
{\rtf1 It's like pretty much always there.}
{\rtf1 200 of 43,000 records are\par missing the organization field.}
{\rtf1 AKA, it's almost always there.}
{\rtf1 So that's one thing we could kick off.}
{\rtf1 Now the trick is, what about malware?}
{\rtf1 When we look at this though, those 200,}
{\rtf1 the ones that we're looking at,}
{\rtf1 the ones that are missing the field,}
{\rtf1 and actually let me\par click on that real quick,}
{\rtf1 let's filter in on this\par to see what these are.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 There's 200 of 'em.}
{\rtf1 We see that a large portion\par of these are from test.int,}
{\rtf1 and we also have these\par other ones over here.}
{\rtf1 Now, if I look at these, ts01.test.int}
{\rtf1 is from the internal domain of test.int.}
{\rtf1 So I'm going to go ahead and remove that.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 Minus that out.}
{\rtf1 There we go.}
{\rtf1 Now when I look at what's left,}
{\rtf1 I see other certificates that are common.}
{\rtf1 So I see machine auth, Microsoft\par security server authority.}
{\rtf1 If we go over here I see\par Microsoft, Microsoft.}
{\rtf1 I see adtdmt, which if you\par look that up it's Microsoft.}
{\rtf1 Storage.live.com,\par bing--those are Microsoft.}
{\rtf1 So one thing I could do is\par go ahead and list for now,}
{\rtf1 filter out this Microsoft one.}
{\rtf1 Still have a few left over.}
{\rtf1 Some of these are still\par related to Microsoft.}
{\rtf1 And we could keep going through these.}
{\rtf1 So the other ones we find if\par I were to filter these out,}
{\rtf1 Microsoft, Intel, Live, Bing.}
{\rtf1 We'd basically be stuck\par with just kind of the one,}
{\rtf1 the vrt certificate authority, and really}
{\rtf1 even if we looked at\par those, those are legitimate}
{\rtf1 domains and certificates.}
{\rtf1 That's still not that much.}
{\rtf1 To filter those out as false\par positives, not a big deal.}
{\rtf1 We went through that fairly quick.}
{\rtf1 Alright, let's go ahead\par and remove these back out.}
{\rtf1 We're going to remove\par the ones we filtered out,}
{\rtf1 and we're going to still\par look at the missing fields}
{\rtf1 for a second.}
{\rtf1 This time we're going\par to hone in on the things}
{\rtf1 not in the top one million domains.}
{\rtf1 Now you see there's 35,000 of\par them that meet that criteria.}
{\rtf1 Let's also just ignore\par test.int to make sure}
{\rtf1 we get rid of that.}
{\rtf1 6,000, so there's a lot\par of internal certificates,}
{\rtf1 which is common, missing that field,}
{\rtf1 because they're auto-issued and they}
{\rtf1 may not have that field.}
{\rtf1 Now external certificate\par sites being accessed though,}
{\rtf1 we still have 6,000.}
{\rtf1 And they're missing multiple fields.}
{\rtf1 In fact, if you look\par at this, if we have one}
{\rtf1 with 6400 certificates in here,}
{\rtf1 almost 4,000 of those are\par missing pretty much every field.}
{\rtf1 So you can see.}
{\rtf1 And also if we look at\par some of the other things}
{\rtf1 we're seeing a lot of\par random domains in here.}
{\rtf1 So there's a lot going wrong in here.}
{\rtf1 Now let's drill down through these.}
{\rtf1 Let's drill down into VMware for a second.}
{\rtf1 VMware is something you might\par have in your environment.}
{\rtf1 Okay, we drill down, wait\par for this search to come up,}
{\rtf1 and we see common name\par issuer, all this information,}
{\rtf1 that looks like a auto\par self-signed local certificate,}
{\rtf1 maybe for vSphere, for\par whatever VMware product}
{\rtf1 is on this network.}
{\rtf1 So this in this case is\par probably a false positive.}
{\rtf1 So we could go ahead and exclude these.}
{\rtf1 Go up here, I'm going to\par flip that to an exclude.}
{\rtf1 What else do we have left?}
{\rtf1 Well, we have got a\par little bit of test pki 01,}
{\rtf1 we have iOS self-signed,\par we have other things}
{\rtf1 we can still look at here.}
{\rtf1 So next let's look at the test pki 01.}
{\rtf1 What the heck is that?}
{\rtf1 Drill down on it.}
{\rtf1 Again, we're going to\par look at some of the logs.}
{\rtf1 We'll go down here soon\par as this is complete.}
{\rtf1 Here we go.}
{\rtf1 If I were to expand one\par of these, we look at it,}
{\rtf1 this is technically for the\par internal domain as well,}
{\rtf1 test.int, but depending\par how the search is submitted}
{\rtf1 sometimes it doesn't work\par the way you're intending.}
{\rtf1 So I'm actually still finding}
{\rtf1 some internal false positives here.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to go ahead and\par flip that to an ignore}
{\rtf1 because we don't care about that either.}
{\rtf1 That leaves this iOS\par self-signed certificate}
{\rtf1 and then what looks to\par be a bunch of gibberish.}
{\rtf1 Let's zoom in on the iOS one.}
{\rtf1 Keep going.}
{\rtf1 If I were to look into this\par and expand one of these,}
{\rtf1 we see the common name ends\par with some type of number}
{\rtf1 and the issuer ends with the same number.}
{\rtf1 Basically it's self-signed,\par it's the same certificate.}
{\rtf1 And there's not a whole\par lot of information here}
{\rtf1 other than it says it's iOS.}
{\rtf1 This would've been something\par I would investigate.}
{\rtf1 What the heck is this?}
{\rtf1 Is this something I expect to see?}
{\rtf1 And in this case this was\par actually an iPad on the network}
{\rtf1 that was using a self-signed\par certificate remotely.}
{\rtf1 It wasn't malicious, but it\par was still unusual to see this,}
{\rtf1 so you investigate it\par and you deal with it.}
{\rtf1 Let's go ahead and filter that out.}
{\rtf1 And now we still have 1300 certificates}
{\rtf1 from contagio in here that\par have random domains in here,}
{\rtf1 they're missing tons of field.}
{\rtf1 This is the data we want to hone in on}
{\rtf1 and we'd want to investigate.}
{\rtf1 Again, this is a lot of\par intentional bad traffic,}
{\rtf1 but in a production\par environment this hopefully}
{\rtf1 would be very minimal and we'd be able}
{\rtf1 to tune out the noise like we just did.}
{\rtf1 So alright.}
{\rtf1 Next let's reload the dashboard}
{\rtf1 so that we can get rid\par of everything in here.}
{\rtf1 Alternatively you can do actions remove,}
{\rtf1 but then you'd also have to remove this.}
{\rtf1 Another way is just\par reloading the dashboard.}
{\rtf1 And that'll bring everything back in.}
{\rtf1 Now what we're going to do\par is look for certificates}
{\rtf1 that are valid for a long time.}
{\rtf1 We'll search for that.}
{\rtf1 We see that there are multiple\par certificates matching this.}
{\rtf1 And what we'll want to\par do is go through these.}
{\rtf1 Again, we're going to analyze this.}
{\rtf1 Is this something I'd want to investigate?}
{\rtf1 Is this something I'd want to filter out?}
{\rtf1 So we'll start by searching\par in on support here}
{\rtf1 since that's the highest quantity.}
{\rtf1 And if we expand this, well\par we can already see up here}
{\rtf1 this starts with the FGT-50E.}
{\rtf1 If you knew this\par environment, that would be}
{\rtf1 a FortiGate 50E device,\par which is a firewall.}
{\rtf1 You expand the logs, you're going to see}
{\rtf1 more information pertaining to Fortinet,}
{\rtf1 because that's what this firewall is.}
{\rtf1 We can see support Fortinet,\par Fortinet, there it is.}
{\rtf1 This is related to Fortinet firewalls.}
{\rtf1 It's not malicious.}
{\rtf1 So we're going to flip\par that to an exclusion.}
{\rtf1 The next thing we're going\par to do is look at what's left.}
{\rtf1 Again we have that iOS\par self-signed certificate.}
{\rtf1 Again I would have wanted\par to investigate that,}
{\rtf1 that was just ended up being the iPad.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to go ahead and filter that out.}
{\rtf1 I then have this primary\par certificate authority.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to zoom in on that\par and see what that's related to.}
{\rtf1 And we can see immediately\par in the frequency score}
{\rtf1 common name this is related to Netflix.}
{\rtf1 So Netflix apparently is using\par a long-running certificate.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to go ahead and filter that out}
{\rtf1 'cause I'm not too\par concerned about Netflix.}
{\rtf1 Now I have web and king.pgsocks.cc.}
{\rtf1 We can see those are the only two domains.}
{\rtf1 Web, well web's not a full domain,}
{\rtf1 so that's weird as well.}
{\rtf1 And king.pgsocks.cc,\par that's an unusual name.}
{\rtf1 You could investigate the\par certificate information,}
{\rtf1 look more at it.}
{\rtf1 There's not a lot of detail there.}
{\rtf1 So that's kind of suspicious.}
{\rtf1 Why are these valid for such a long time?}
{\rtf1 Could be normal, maybe not.}
{\rtf1 But these are things\par we'd want to investigate.}
{\rtf1 So false positive reduction here}
{\rtf1 does not have to be so hard.}
{\rtf1 The investigating the weird\par ones that are left over though,}
{\rtf1 that can take some time,\par but it's worth the effort.}
{\rtf1 This is where you could find malware}
{\rtf1 and other things penned\par up in your environment.}
{\rtf1 Now we could keep going with this.}
{\rtf1 Again I'm going to reload the dashboard,}
{\rtf1 and this time we're going to\par look for frequency scores.}
{\rtf1 So here I'm looking for round domain names}
{\rtf1 and seeing what's going on.}
{\rtf1 I'm going to start by\par looking for certificates}
{\rtf1 that have a frequency\par score less than five.}
{\rtf1 So out of 85,000, we went\par down and 1100 of them}
{\rtf1 have frequency scores below a five.}
{\rtf1 Alright, so that might\par be fairly high fidelity,}
{\rtf1 but let's test that theory.}
{\rtf1 How many of those would've\par ended up in the top one million?}
{\rtf1 123, so that means false\par positive rate of 10% roughly.}
{\rtf1 That's kind of brutal.}
{\rtf1 Now 123 is not that\par bad, but is that really}
{\rtf1 what you want to deal with?}
{\rtf1 So let's play with the\par numbers a little bit.}
{\rtf1 What if we did something like same thing}
{\rtf1 but the length of the field being checked}
{\rtf1 for natural language processing}
{\rtf1 is greater than 16 characters in length?}
{\rtf1 Now that brings that down\par to only 4 false positives.}
{\rtf1 So the more characters in a string,}
{\rtf1 the better chance we can accurately do}
{\rtf1 natural language processing.}
{\rtf1 So I could change how I'm doing this,}
{\rtf1 whether it's an automated\par alert or a dashboard,}
{\rtf1 so that I'm only looking for things}
{\rtf1 that have longer domain names.}
{\rtf1 Because shorter domains\par are being sold out,}
{\rtf1 and it's harder to get access to.}
{\rtf1 It's not impossible, but\par it's harder to get access to.}
{\rtf1 Where random domain generation\par tends to be longer domains.}
{\rtf1 So this might work.}
{\rtf1 And then here we only\par have four false positives.}
{\rtf1 Much easier to deal with.}
{\rtf1 Alright, now how many of these are not}
{\rtf1 in the top one million?}
{\rtf1 933, so earlier when we weren't doing}
{\rtf1 a 16-character length\par check, there was 1123.}
{\rtf1 So we would've missed 200 of these,}
{\rtf1 but I only had four false\par positives this time.}
{\rtf1 So you see the trade-off here?}
{\rtf1 A little bit of false positives}
{\rtf1 versus a ton of false positives.}
{\rtf1 Catching everything but being drowned}
{\rtf1 by too many false positives versus}
{\rtf1 catching a lot and missing a little.}
{\rtf1 And again, we're combining these}
{\rtf1 with all the different\par techniques we talked about 555,}
{\rtf1 so I'm not overly concerned that}
{\rtf1 I would've missed some of these.}
{\rtf1 Because hopefully I'm\par catching them somewhere else.}
{\rtf1 But we have to find that trade-off,}
{\rtf1 because if you're just\par drowning in false positives,}
{\rtf1 you're drowning, so we need to fix that.}
{\rtf1 One other thing we can do\par is look for certificates}
{\rtf1 with invalid information in here.}
{\rtf1 So for this I'm just going to submit}
{\rtf1 a really long search\par looking at the issuer state.}
{\rtf1 I'm basically looking for\par things in the United States}
{\rtf1 that for instance if it\par says it's in Illinois}
{\rtf1 it should be spelled\par right or it should be IL,}
{\rtf1 the abbreviated name.}
{\rtf1 There's only so many states in the U.S.,}
{\rtf1 so if I search this I find 33 records,}
{\rtf1 really just a few certificates}
{\rtf1 that have improper issuer states.}
{\rtf1 And you can see they're\par not filled out correctly.}
{\rtf1 Common name pipe your name web.}
{\rtf1 InvalidSSL.host.com.}
{\rtf1 Things like this.}
{\rtf1 So multiple ways we can\par investigate certificates}
{\rtf1 and see what's going on.}
{\rtf1 We can do things like frequency analysis.}
{\rtf1 We can look for invalid data\par such as the state field.}
{\rtf1 We can look for missing fields.}
{\rtf1 We can look for long expiring domains}
{\rtf1 or short expirations.}
{\rtf1 There's a lot of things we can do}
{\rtf1 without having to analyze the payload.}
{\rtf1 You should be doing certificate analysis}
{\rtf1 and looking at things.}
{\rtf1 Adversaries use encryption\par to bypass our controls,}
{\rtf1 evade them, get past blacklists,}
{\rtf1 and to make it where we can't see them.}
{\rtf1 But again, what we want to do is take}
{\rtf1 all the things they're doing}
{\rtf1 and try to flip it around so that}
{\rtf1 we can turn their\par strengths into a weakness.}
{\rtf1 And by analyzing certificates,}
{\rtf1 that's one of the ways we can do this.}
